etymologies: late Middle English (denoting contraction, such as that of a muscle): from French, or from medieval Latin tractio(n-), from Latin trahere ‘draw, pull’. Current senses date from the early 19th century

definitions: the action of drawing or pulling something over a surface, especially a road or track

examples.text: a primitive vehicle used in animal traction

shortDefinitions: action of drawing something over surface

definitions: motive power provided for movement, especially on a railroad

examples.text: the changeover to diesel and electric traction

shortDefinitions: motive power provided to draw or pull something

examples.text: a pent-up demand for traction and rolling stock

definitions: the grip of a tire on a road or a wheel on a rail

examples.text: his car hit a patch of ice and lost traction

shortDefinitions: grip of tyre on road or wheel on rail

definitions: the extent to which a product, idea, etc., gains popularity or acceptance

examples.text: analysts predicted that the technology would rapidly gain traction in the corporate market
if a film got a little traction, a wider release could be negotiated

shortDefinitions: extent to which idea, product, etc. gains popularity or acceptance

definitions: the application of a sustained pull on a limb or muscle, especially in order to maintain the position of a fractured bone or to correct a deformity
shortDefinitions: application of sustained pull on limb or muscle
